sen.j: 田口 卯吉（たぐち うきち、1855年6月12日（安政2年4月29日_(旧暦)） - 1905年4月13日）は、日本の経済学者・歴史家。
sen.e: Ukichi TAGUCHI (June 12 1855-14 April 1905) was a Japanese economist and historian.
Ukichi TAGUCHI (June 13, 1855 - 14 April 1905) was a Japanese economist and historian.
sen.cmt: 日付表記を修正(原文に1855年6月12日とありますが、1855年6月13日の誤りと思われます)
sen.e: Ukichi TAGUCHI (June 13, 1855 - 14 April 1905) was a Japanese economist and historian.

sen.j: 東京府会議員（明治13年（1880年）12月-明治23年（1890年）7月）、衆議院議員（明治27年（1894年）10月-明治38年（1905年）2月）なども歴任した。
sen.e: He was a member of the Tokyo Assembly (December 1880 to July 1890) and a member of the House of Representatives (October 1894-February 1905).
He was a member of the Tokyo Assembly (December 1880 to July 1890) and a member of the House of Representatives (October 1894-February 1905).
He was a member of the Tokyo Assembly (December 1880 to July 1890) and a member of the House of Representatives (October 1894-February 1905).

sen.j: 名は生年が乙卯であることにちなむ。
sen.e: His name, meaning "Yin Wood Rabbit", is associated with the year he was born in the Chinese sexagenary cycle.
His name, meaning "Yin Wood Rabbit," is associated with the year he was born in the Chinese sexagenary cycle.
sen.cmt: カンマの位置を移動しました。
sen.e: His name, meaning "Yin Wood Rabbit," is associated with the year he was born in the Chinese sexagenary cycle.

sen.j: 名は鉉（みつ）。
sen.e: His real first name was Mitsu.
His real first name was Mitsu.
His real first name was Mitsu.

sen.j: 卯吉は通称。
sen.e: Ukichi was his common name.
Ukichi was his common name.
Ukichi was his common name.

sen.j: 字は子玉。
sen.e: His Chinese style name (courtesy name) was Kotama.
His Chinese style name (courtesy name) was Shigyoku (子玉).
sen.cmt: Kotama→Shigyokuとし、漢字表記を追加しました。
sen.e: His Chinese style name (courtesy name) was Shigyoku (子玉).

sen.j: 号は鼎軒で、『易経』に由来。
sen.e: His pen name was Teiken which came from I Ching (the Book of Changes).
His pen name was Teiken which came from "I Ching" (the Book of Changes).
sen.cmt: 原文に合わせクォーテーション追加しました。
sen.e: His pen name was Teiken which came from "I Ching" (the Book of Changes).

sen.j: 略歴
sen.e: Background
Brief Personal History
sen.cmt: 統一リストの表記に修正しました。
sen.e: Brief Personal History

sen.j: 幕臣の子で、江戸目白台の徒士屋敷（現東京都文京区目白台の日本女子大学敷地内）に生まれる。
sen.e: The child of a shogunate retainer, TAGUCHI was born in Mejirodai, Edo (Tokyo), in the residences of low class samurai (current day grounds of Japan Women's University in Bunkyo Ward, Tokyo).
The child of a shogunate retainer, Taguchi was born in Mejirodai, Edo (Tokyo), in the residences of low class samurai (current day grounds of Japan Women's University in Bunkyo Ward, Tokyo).
The child of a shogunate retainer, Taguchi was born in Mejirodai, Edo (Tokyo), in the residences of low class samurai (current day grounds of Japan Women's University in Bunkyo Ward, Tokyo).

sen.j: 父は西山家から養子に入った樫郎、母は町子。
sen.e: His father's name was Kashiro, who was adopted from the Nishiyama family, and his mother was Machiko.
His father's name was Kashiro, who was adopted from the Nishiyama family, and his mother was Machiko.
His father's name was Kashiro, who was adopted from the Nishiyama family, and his mother was Machiko.

sen.j: 田口家は初代右衛門が将軍徳川吉宗の従士として使えて以来の家系で、のちに零落し、天保12年（1841年）に佐藤一斎が株を買い、一斎の長男である慎左衛門が継ぐ。
sen.e: The TAGUCHI family linage goes back to Hatsushiro Emon TAGUCHI who served as a jushi (junior samurai) for Tokugawa Yoshimune, but the family later fell on hard times and in 1841 their assets were bought by Issai SATO to be inherited by his eldest son Shinsaemon.

The Taguchi family linage goes back to the founder Uemon TAGUCHI who served as a jushi (junior samurai) for Shogun Yoshimune TOKUGAWA, but the family later fell on hard times and in 1841 their assets were bought by Issai SATO to be inherited by his eldest son Shinzaemon.
sen.cmt: 「将軍」→訳漏れのため訳出、TAGUCHI→Taguchiとし、Hatsushiro Emon TAGUCHI→the founder Uemon TAGUCHI、Tokugawa Yoshimune→Yoshimune TOKUGAWA、Shinsaemon→Shinzaemonに修正しました。
sen.e: The Taguchi family linage goes back to the founder Uemon TAGUCHI who served as a jushi (junior samurai) for Shogun Yoshimune TOKUGAWA, but the family later fell on hard times and in 1841 their assets were bought by Issai SATO to be inherited by his eldest son Shinzaemon.

sen.j: 慎左衛門の娘町子は井上家に嫁いだ後に後家となり、樫郎を婿に迎えた。
sen.e: Shinsaemon's daughter Machiko, who initially married into the Inoue family but was later widowed, took Kashiro has her husband.
Shinzaemon's daughter Machiko, who initially married into the Inoue family but was later widowed, took Kashiro as her husband.
Shinzaemon's daughter Machiko, who initially married into the Inoue family but was later widowed, took Kashiro as her husband.

sen.j: 安政6年（1859年）に父の樫郎、翌年には長兄の貫一郎が相次いで死去し、家督を相続。
sen.e: In 1859, his father Kashiro died and the following year his elder brother died, making him head of the household.
In 1859, his father Kashiro died and the following year his older brother died, making him head of the household.
sen.cmt: 統一リストに基づき、elder brother→older brotherに修正しました。
sen.e: In 1859, his father Kashiro died and the following year his older brother died, making him head of the household.

sen.j: 慶応2年（1866年）に元服して従士見習いとなるが、12月に幕府の軍制改革で従士組が廃止され、新設の銃隊に配属される。
sen.e: In 1866 he underwent his coming of age ceremony and began his jushi (junior samurai) training, but in December the jushi system was abolished through military reforms of the shoganate and he was assigned to the rifle corps.

In 1866 he underwent his coming of age ceremony and began his jushi (junior samurai) training, but in January 1867 the jushi system was abolished through military reforms of the shoganate and he was assigned to the rifle corps.
sen.cmt: 旧暦→新暦に修正しました。
sen.e: In 1866 he underwent his coming of age ceremony and began his jushi (junior samurai) training, but in January 1867 the jushi system was abolished through military reforms of the shoganate and he was assigned to the rifle corps.

sen.j: また、昌平坂学問所でも学んでいる。
sen.e: He also studied at the Shoheizaka School.
He also studied at the Shoheizaka School.
He also studied at the Shoheizaka School.

sen.j: 同年には異父姉の鐙子が但馬出石藩の儒家木村熊二に嫁ぎ、田口家も下谷の木村家と同居する。
sen.e: In the same year his elder half sister Toko married the Confucianist Kumaji KIMURA of Izushi Domain, Tajima Province, resulting in the Taguchi family and the Kimura family of Shimotani living together.

In the same year his older maternal half-sister Toko married the Confucianist Kumaji KIMURA of Izushi Domain, Tajima Province, resulting in the Taguchi family and the Kimura family of Shimotani living together.
sen.cmt: 統一リストに基づき、elder half sister→older maternal half-sisterに修正しました。
sen.e: In the same year his older maternal half-sister Toko married the Confucianist Kumaji KIMURA of Izushi Domain, Tajima Province, resulting in the Taguchi family and the Kimura family of Shimotani living together.

sen.j: 近所の従士目付乙骨太郎乙とも親交があった。
sen.e: He became close friends with Taroitsu OTSUKOTSU, a local metsuke (inspector).
He became close friends with Tarootsu OTSUKOTSU, a local metsuke (inspector).
sen.cmt: Taroitsu OTSUKOTSU→Tarootsu OTSUKOTSUに修正しました。(参照:http://kotobank.jp/word/%E4%B9%99%E9%AA%A8%E5%A4%AA%E9%83%8E%E4%B9%99)
sen.e: He became close friends with Tarootsu OTSUKOTSU, a local metsuke (inspector).

sen.j: 明治維新による幕府瓦解において義兄の熊二は彰義隊を支援するなど抵抗し、田口家は横浜へ逃れ商売を行う。
sen.e: Resisting brother-in-law Kumaji's support of the Shogitai (former Tokugawa retainers opposed to Meiji government) following the collapse of the shogunate and beginning of the Meiji Restoration, the Takguchi family escaped to Yokohama and started a business.

Resisting brother-in-law Kumaji's support of the Shogitai (former Tokugawa retainers opposed to the Meiji government) following the collapse of the shogunate and beginning of the Meiji Restoration, the Takguchi family escaped to Yokohama and started a business.

Resisting brother-in-law Kumaji's support of the Shogitai (former Tokugawa retainers opposed to the Meiji government) following the collapse of the shogunate and beginning of the Meiji Restoration, the Takguchi family escaped to Yokohama and started a business.

sen.j: 卯吉は乙骨の勧めで旧幕臣の経営する骨董屋で働き、アメリカ長老派の宣教師に英語を学ぶ。
sen.e: UKICHI, on the advice of OTSUKOTSU, worked at an antique shop run by a former retainer of the shogun, and studied English under American Presbyterian missionaries.
Ukichi, on the advice of Otsukotsu, worked at an antique shop run by a former retainer of the shogun, and studied English under American Presbyterian missionaries.
Ukichi, on the advice of Otsukotsu, worked at an antique shop run by a former retainer of the shogun, and studied English under American Presbyterian missionaries.

sen.j: 明治元年（1868年）に徳川家の静岡移封に伴い沼津へ移住し、沼津兵学校で英語教師をしていた乙骨のもとへ寄宿する。
sen.e: In 1868 when the Tokugawa family relocated to Shizuoka he moved to Numazu and lodged at the house of OTSUKOTSU who was working as an English instructor at the Numazu Officer Academy.
In 1868 when the Tokugawa family relocated to Shizuoka he moved to Numazu and lodged at the house of Otsukotsu who was working as an English instructor at the Numazu Officer Academy.
In 1868 when the Tokugawa family relocated to Shizuoka he moved to Numazu and lodged at the house of Otsukotsu who was working as an English instructor at the Numazu Officer Academy.

sen.j: 兵学校で学び、中根淑の漢学塾でも学ぶ。
sen.e: He studied at the officer academy and also studied Sinology under Kiyoshi NAKANE.
He studied at the officer academy and also studied Sinology under Kiyoshi NAKANE.
He studied at the officer academy and also studied Sinology under Kiyoshi NAKANE.

sen.j: 兵学校時代に島田三郎と知り合い、中根塾では伊庭想太郎らと交友している。
sen.e: While at the officer academy he became acquainted with Saburo SHIMADA, and at NAKANE's school became friends with people such as Sotaro IBA.
While at the officer academy he became acquainted with Saburo SHIMADA, and at Nakane's school became friends with people such as Sotaro IBA.
While at the officer academy he became acquainted with Saburo SHIMADA, and at Nakane's school became friends with people such as Sotaro IBA.

sen.j: 明治2年（1869年）に生育方に付くが同年9月に廃止され、義兄の熊二や父の実家西山家の周旋で沼津勤番組に配属される。
sen.e: In 1869 he was to be attached to the Seichoho, but it was abolished in September of the same year, and at the recommendation of his bother-in-law Kumaji and his real father (from the Nishiyama family), he was assigned to the Numazu Kibangumi.
sen.cmt: I'm not sure what 生育方 is.
sen.e: In 1869 he was to be attached to the Seiikugata (生育方), but it was abolished in October of the same year, and at the recommendation of his bother-in-law Kumaji and his father's house, the Nishiyama family, he was assigned to the Numazu Kinbangumi.
sen.cmt: Seichoho→Seiikugataとし、読みが不確かなため漢字表記追加、旧暦→新暦に修正、his real father (from the Nishiyama family)→his father's house, the Nishiyama family、Kibangumi→Kinbangumiに修正しました。
sen.e: In 1869 he was to be attached to the Seiikugata (生育方), but it was abolished in October of the same year, and at the recommendation of his bother-in-law Kumaji and his father's house, the Nishiyama family, he was assigned to the Numazu Kinbangumi.

sen.j: 明治3年（1870年）9月に第六期資業生試験に合格し、12月には静岡市立静岡病院での医学修行を拝命する。
sen.e: In 1870 TAGUCHI passed the sixth class exam at the officer academy and in December received an official appointment to study medicine at Shizuoka Hospital.
In September 1870 Taguchi passed the sixth class exam at the officer academy and in January 1871 received an official appointment to study medicine at Shizuoka Hospital.
sen.cmt: 「9月」→訳漏れのため訳出、旧暦→新暦に修正、TAGUCHI→Taguchiとしました。
sen.e: In September 1870 Taguchi passed the sixth class exam at the officer academy and in January 1871 received an official appointment to study medicine at Shizuoka Hospital.

sen.j: また、義兄の熊二はこのころ海外渡航し、卯吉は家長の立場となる。
sen.e: Also, his brother-in-law Kumaji left for abroad at this time putting Ukichi at the head of the family.
Also, his brother-in-law Kumaji left for abroad at this time putting Ukichi at the head of the family.
Also, his brother-in-law Kumaji left for abroad at this time putting Ukichi at the head of the family.

sen.j: 明治4年（1871年）廃藩置県で静岡藩が解消され主な人材が東京へ移ると、卯吉も乙骨とともに上京する。
sen.e: In 1871 Shizuoka Domain was dissolved at the abolishment of feudal domains and the establishment of prefectures, and many men of talent, Ukichi and OTSUKOTSU, moved to Tokyo.
In 1871 Shizuoka Domain was dissolved at the Haihan-chiken (abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures), and many men of talent, Ukichi and Otsukotsu, moved to Tokyo.
sen.cmt: 「廃藩置県」→統一リストの表記に修正、OTSUKOTSU→Otsukotsuとしました。
sen.e: In 1871 Shizuoka Domain was dissolved at the Haihan-chiken (abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures), and many men of talent, Ukichi and Otsukotsu, moved to Tokyo.

sen.j: 島田とともに薬屋を志し、開校予定の科学専門学校に応募するが開校は中止となり、大学予備門に入学するがほどなく退学している。
sen.e: He set his sights on running a pharmacy with SHIMADA and applied to a science academy that was soon to be opening, but the opening was suspended so he entered a university preparation school but soon after dropped out.

He set his sights on running a pharmacy with Shimada and applied to a science academy that was soon to be opening, but the opening was suspended so he entered a university preparation school but soon after dropped out.

He set his sights on running a pharmacy with Shimada and applied to a science academy that was soon to be opening, but the opening was suspended so he entered a university preparation school but soon after dropped out.

sen.j: 尺振八の私立共立学舎に入学し、翌明治5年（1872年）に大蔵大輔井上馨と渋沢栄一が人材育成機関として構想した大蔵省翻訳局が発足し、乙骨や尺が登用されると島田とともに応募し上等生徒となる。
sen.e: He entered Shimpachi SEKI's private school, and in the following year (1872) after OTSUKOTSU and SEKI were hired by the Ministry of Finance translation bureau - an office conceived by Minister of Finance vice secretary Kaoru INOUE and Eichi SHIBUSAWA for training talented individuals - Ukichi and Shimada applied and were accepted there as first class students.

He entered Shinpachi SEKI's private school, and in the following year (1872) after Otsukotsu and Seki were hired by the Ministry of Finance translation bureau - an office conceived by Minister of Finance vice secretary Kaoru INOUE and Eiichi SHIBUSAWA for training talented individuals - Ukichi and Shimada applied and were accepted there as first class students.
sen.cmt: Shimpachi→Shinpachi、Eichi SHIBUSAWA→Eiichi SHIBUSAWAに修正、OTSUKOTSU and SEKI→Otsukotsu and Sekiとし、余分なスペース消去しました。
sen.e: He entered Shinpachi SEKI's private school, and in the following year (1872) after Otsukotsu and Seki were hired by the Ministry of Finance translation bureau - an office conceived by Minister of Finance vice secretary Kaoru INOUE and Eiichi SHIBUSAWA for training talented individuals - Ukichi and Shimada applied and were accepted there as first class students.

sen.j: 翻訳局では経済学や西洋文明史が教授され、このころにフランソワ・ピエール・ギヨーム・ギゾーなどの影響を受け医科から転向したといわれ、またキリスト教にも接している。
sen.e: At the translation bureau he took classes on economics and the history of Western civilisation, and in this time was influenced by the works of men such as Francois Guizot, focussing his attention away from medicine, and also coming into contact with Christianity.

At the translation bureau he took classes on economics and the history of Western civilisation, and in this time was influenced by the works of men such as Francois GUIZOT, focussing his attention away from medicine, and also coming into contact with Christianity.
sen.cmt: 仕様書に基づき、Francois Guizot→Francois GUIZOTに修正しました。
sen.e: At the translation bureau he took classes on economics and the history of Western civilisation, and in this time was influenced by the works of men such as Francois GUIZOT, focussing his attention away from medicine, and also coming into contact with Christianity.

sen.j: だが、明治6年（1873年）に井上や渋沢が辞し、続いて大蔵卿に大隈重信が就くと組織改変で翻訳局は縮小され、翌年には廃止となり卯吉は大蔵省紙幣寮に異動となる。
sen.e: However, In 1973 INOUE and SHIBUSAWA resigned, and when the Shigenobu OKUMA took office as Minister of Finance the translation bureau was curtailed through a ministry reorganisation and abolished the following year, forcing Ukichi to transfer to the ministry's department for currency.

However, in 1873 Inoue and Shibusawa resigned, and when the Shigenobu OKUMA took office as Minister of Finance the translation bureau was curtailed through a ministry reorganisation and abolished the following year, forcing Ukichi to transfer to the ministry's department for currency.
sen.cmt: INOUE and SHIBUSAWA→Inoue and Shibusawaとし、In 1973→in 1873に修正しました。
sen.e: However, in 1873 Inoue and Shibusawa resigned, and when the Shigenobu OKUMA took office as Minister of Finance the translation bureau was curtailed through a ministry reorganisation and abolished the following year, forcing Ukichi to transfer to the ministry's department for currency.

sen.j: 明治9年には旧幕臣の娘千代と結婚。
sen.e: In 1876 he married Chiyo, the daughter of a former retainer of the shogun.
In 1876 he married Chiyo, the daughter of a former retainer of the shogun.
In 1876 he married Chiyo, the daughter of a former retainer of the shogun.

sen.j: 著述活動をはじめ、明治10年（1877年）に自費出版で『日本開化小史』を刊行開始。
sen.e: In 1877 he began self-publishing with his publication Nippon Kaika Shoshi (Short History of Japanese Civilization).
In 1877 he began self-publishing with his publication "Nihon Kaika Shoshi" (Short History of Japanese Civilization).
sen.cmt: Nippon Kaika Shoshi→Nihon Kaika Shoshiに修正、原文に合わせクォーテーション追加しました。(参照: http://dic.yahoo.co.jp/dsearch/0/0ss/114952300000/)
sen.e: In 1877 he began self-publishing with his publication "Nihon Kaika Shoshi" (Short History of Japanese Civilization).

sen.j: 翌明治11年（1878年）には『自由交易日本経済経済論』を出版。
sen.e: The following year in 1878 he published Jiyu Boeki Nippon Keizai Ron (A study of free trade and the Japanese economy).
The following year in 1878 he published "Jiyu Koeki Nihon Keizai Ron" (A study of free trade and the Japanese economy).
sen.cmt: Jiyu Boeki Nippon Keizai Ron→Jiyu Koeki Nihon Keizai Ronに修正、原文に合わせクォーテーション追加しました。
sen.e: The following year in 1878 he published "Jiyu Koeki Nihon Keizai Ron" (A study of free trade and the Japanese economy).

sen.j: 同年には沼間守一らの嚶鳴社設立に島田とともに発起人として参加し、演説活動も行っている。
sen.e: The same year he participated as an activist with SHIMADA in the Omeisha, an organization to promote liberalism established by Morikazu NUMA.
The same year he participated as an activist with Shimada in the Omeisha, an organization to promote liberalism established by Morikazu NUMA.
The same year he participated as an activist with Shimada in the Omeisha, an organization to promote liberalism established by Morikazu NUMA.

sen.j: 翌明治12年（1879年）に大蔵省を辞職し、翻訳業を手がけつつ新聞への投書や著述活動を行い、同年にはイギリスの『エコノミスト』誌を範とした『東京経済雑誌』を創刊し、自由主義の立場での論陣を張った。
sen.e: In 1879 he left the Ministry of Finance and wrote editorials and articles for newspapers while working as a translator, eventually launching his own magazine, the liberally aligned Tokyo Keizai Zasshi (Tokyo Economics Magazine) modelled on the British 'Economist' magazine.

In 1879 he left the Ministry of Finance and wrote editorials and articles for newspapers while working as a translator, eventually launching his own magazine, the liberally aligned "Tokyo Keizai Zasshi" (Tokyo Economics Magazine) modelled on the British "Economist" magazine in the same year.
sen.cmt: 「同年には」→訳漏れのため訳出、原文に合わせクォーテーション表記修正しました。
sen.e: In 1879 he left the Ministry of Finance and wrote editorials and articles for newspapers while working as a translator, eventually launching his own magazine, the liberally aligned "Tokyo Keizai Zasshi" (Tokyo Economics Magazine) modelled on the British "Economist" magazine in the same year.

sen.j: 明治13年（1880年）には東京府会議員となり、憲法制定や、条約改正などの政治問題に関しても発言。
sen.e: In 1880 he became a Tokyo Prefectural councilor, often giving speeches on political issues such as the constitution and the revision of treaties.
In 1880 he became a Tokyo Prefectural councilor, often giving speeches on political issues such as the constitution and the revision of treaties.
In 1880 he became a Tokyo Prefectural councilor, often giving speeches on political issues such as the constitution and the revision of treaties.

sen.j: 自由党 (日本)機関紙『自由新聞』の客員も務める。
sen.e: He also worked as a guest columnist for the Jiyu Shimbun (Freedom Newspaper), the official publication of the Liberal Party.
He also worked as a guest columnist for the "Jiyu Shinbun" (Freedom Newspaper), the official publication of the Liberal Party.
He also worked as a guest columnist for the "Jiyu Shinbun" (Freedom Newspaper), the official publication of the Liberal Party.

sen.j: 実業家としては、東京府知事高崎五六から提案された府の士族授産金処理事業としての南洋交易を引き受け、明治23年（1890年）に南島商会を組織し、貿易船天祐丸で南洋渡航を行う。
sen.e: As a businessman he became active in a South Seas trading venture at the suggestion of Tokyo governor Goroku (Itsumu) TAKASAKI, which was funded by shizoku jusan kin (grants for the retraining of samurai), and in 1890 formed the Nanto (South Sea Islands) Company, voyaging to the South Seas on the Tenyu (Heaven's Help) trading vessel.

As a businessman he became active in a South Seas trading venture at the suggestion of Tokyo governor Goroku (Itsumu) TAKASAKI, which was funded by shizoku jusan kin (grants for the retraining of samurai), and in 1890 formed the Nanto (South Sea Islands) Company, voyaging to the South Seas on the Tenyu Maru (Heaven's Help) trading vessel.

As a businessman he became active in a South Seas trading venture at the suggestion of Tokyo governor Goroku (Itsumu) TAKASAKI, which was funded by shizoku jusan kin (grants for the retraining of samurai), and in 1890 formed the Nanto (South Sea Islands) Company, voyaging to the South Seas on the Tenyu Maru (Heaven's Help) trading vessel.

sen.j: 東京株式取引所（現東京証券取引所）、鉄道経営においては明治20年（1887年）に両毛鉄道社長、21年に小田原電気鉄道（現箱根登山鉄道）取締役などを務める。
sen.e: In 1887 he worked at the Tokyo Stock Exchange and in railway administration, becoming the president of the Ryomo Railway Company, and in 1888 served as director of the Odawara Tramway Company (now the Hakone Tozon Railway Company).

In 1887 he worked at the Tokyo Stock Exchange and in railway administration, becoming the president of the Ryomo Railway Company, and in 1888 served as director of the Odawara Tramway Company (now the Hakone Tozon Railway Company).

In 1887 he worked at the Tokyo Stock Exchange and in railway administration, becoming the president of the Ryomo Railway Company, and in 1888 served as director of the Odawara Tramway Company (now the Hakone Tozon Railway Company).

sen.j: 明治23年（1890年）には府会副議長となり、明治27年（1894年）には尾崎三良らと帝国財政革新会を結成し、この年には衆議院議員に当選する。
sen.e: In 1890 TAGUCHI became deputy chairman of the Tokyo assembly, and in 1894 formed a council for reform of imperial financial affairs (the Teikoku Zaisei Kakushin Kai) with Saburo OZAKI, and was also elected a member of the House of Representatives the same year.

In 1890 Taguchi became deputy chairman of the Tokyo assembly, and in 1894 formed a council for reform of imperial financial affairs (the Teikoku Zaisei Kakushin Kai) with Saburo OZAKI, and was also elected a member of the House of Representatives the same year.

In 1890 Taguchi became deputy chairman of the Tokyo assembly, and in 1894 formed a council for reform of imperial financial affairs (the Teikoku Zaisei Kakushin Kai) with Saburo OZAKI, and was also elected a member of the House of Representatives the same year.

sen.j: 明治29年（1896年）には進歩党 (日本)を結成、明治30年（1897年）には島田三郎らと財政整理期成同盟会を組織する。
sen.e: In 1896 he formed the Shimpoto (Progressive Party), and in 1897 set up a council for financial adjustment with Saburo SHIMADA.
In 1896 he formed the Shinpoto (Progressive Party), and in 1897 set up a council for financial adjustment with Saburo SHIMADA.
In 1896 he formed the Shinpoto (Progressive Party), and in 1897 set up a council for financial adjustment with Saburo SHIMADA.

sen.j: 明治31年（1898年）、憲政会創設委員に参加。
sen.e: In 1898 he participated in the foundation of the Kenseikai political party.
In 1898 he participated in the foundation of the Kenseikai political party.
In 1898 he participated in the foundation of the Kenseikai political party.

sen.j: 明治32年（1899年）には法学博士となる。
sen.e: In 1899 he received a doctorate in judicial studies.
In 1899 he received a doctorate in judicial studies.
In 1899 he received a doctorate in judicial studies.

sen.j: 明治33年（1900年）、北清事変に際して視察を行う。
sen.e: In 1890 he went to China to observe the Boxer Rebellion.
In 1900 he went to China to observe the Boxer Rebellion.
In 1900 he went to China to observe the Boxer Rebellion.

sen.j: 『国史大系』『群書類従』を編纂。
sen.e: He compiled the Kokushi Taikei (Compendium of Japanese History) and the Gunsho Ruiju (Classified Collection of Books).
He compiled the "Kokushi Taikei" (Compendium of Japanese History) and the "Gunsho Ruiju" (Classified Collection of Books).
sen.cmt: 原文表記に合わせクォーテーション追加しました。
sen.e: He compiled the "Kokushi Taikei" (Compendium of Japanese History) and the "Gunsho Ruiju" (Classified Collection of Books).

sen.j: 享年51．
sen.e: He was 51 when he died.
He died at the age of 51.
sen.cmt: 統一リストの表記に修正しました。
sen.e: He died at the age of 51.

sen.j: 『自由貿易日本経済論』
sen.e: Jiyu Boeki Nippon Keizairon (A Study of Free Trade and the Japanese Economy)
"Jiyu Boeki Nihon Keizairon" (A Study of Free Trade and the Japanese Economy)
sen.cmt: Nippon→Nihonに修正、原文表記に合わせクォーテーション追加しました。(*「貿易」→「交易」の誤りと思われますがあえてそのままにしております。参考: http://porta.ndl.go.jp/Result/R000000008/I000056130)
sen.e: "Jiyu Boeki Nihon Keizairon" (A Study of Free Trade and the Japanese Economy)

sen.j: 『日本開化小史』岩波文庫、講談社学術文庫がある。
sen.e: Nippon Kaika Shoshi (Short History of Japanese Civilization), Iwanami Bunko, Academic paperback library, Kodansha Ltd.
"Nihon Kaika Shoshi" (Short History of Japanese Civilization), Iwanami Bunko, Academic paperback library, Kodansha Ltd.

sen.e: "Nihon Kaika Shoshi" (Short History of Japanese Civilization), Iwanami Bunko, Academic paperback library, Kodansha Ltd.

sen.j: 『日本之意匠及情交』

sen.j: 『大日本人名辞典』
sen.e: Dainihon Jinmei Jiten (Dictionary of Japanese Biography)
sen.cmt: Refer: Japanese Historians and the National Myths, 1600-1945: The Age of the Gods, p.83
sen.e: "Dainihon Jinmei Jiten" (Dictionary of Japanese Biography)
